As Schmitt so astutely observed, "Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way" (1974, p. 109), a shift in the balance of power that would signal the beginning of the end of their animosity. And as the United States's ambitions turned from territorial expansion to economic intervention, the rival nations began to find common ground, their relations slowly healing from the wounds of the past.

The weight of it settled upon me like a shroud, fifteen years ago, a darkness that crept in without warning, an illness that had lain in wait, its presence unknown to me until it had claimed me as its own. I was a nurse, then, a profession born of necessity, a shield against the uncertainties of my own childhood. The mantra echoed in my mind, a refrain I had heard since adolescence: "You'll always find work, for people will always fall ill." And so I chose the path of healing, a way to temper the vulnerabilities of my past. Yet, it was not the path of my dreams, for I had once aspired to be a scientist, to unravel the mysteries of the world, or a journalist, to chronicle its stories.

Now, at the age of forty-six, I found myself alone, my bank account barren, my body broken. The Social Security Disability checks that sustained me were a meager lifeline, a reminder of the fragility of existence. Fifteen years had passed, and I had nothing left that was truly mine. Each day was a struggle, an assault on my very being, a constant reminder that security, safety, and self-worth were fleeting concepts. Yet, amidst this desolation, I knew one thing to be true: I would not have endured without the kindness of family and friends, their unwavering support a testament to the power of human connection.

In the face of disaster, we are not as strong as we believe. It is in these moments of calamity that we discover the truth of our own vulnerability. And it is here that I find solace in the idea that we should not rely solely on the benevolence of a crumbling system, but rather on each other. The notion of rugged individualism, so dear to the hearts of some, is a myth, a palliative for the ailing souls of those who would have us believe that we can weather any storm alone.

Our forebears, those pioneers who traversed the treacherous terrain of the Rockies, did not reach the promised land through solitary endeavors, but through the sharing of resources, the bond of community, and the compassion that fostered it. They knew that in the face of uncertainty, it is not the individual who stands strong, but the collective.

I, too, have prepared for the worst. I have stockpiled supplies, a meager arsenal against the unknown: a disaster kit, first aid supplies, water purifying tablets, and the faint glimmer of hope that these will be enough. But I know that it is not the accumulation of goods that will see me through, but the threads of connection that bind me to those around me. If you have the means, cultivate a small farm, preserve your own food, and tend a wood stove. But do not forget the most essential ingredient in the recipe for resilience: the knowledge of your neighbors.

In the grand tapestry of life, the thread of evolution weaves its intricate pattern, a testament to the unfathomable complexity of the natural world. The question lingers, a specter haunting the halls of biology, why do organisms unfold as they do? What unseen forces shape the trajectory of their development, guiding the course of their transformation? Since the dawn of modern science, the enigmatic D'Arcy Thompson posited that the zoologist's grasp of organic forms remains as elusive as a mirage on a desert horizon, tantalizing yet forever out of reach. Even now, a century later, the same sentiment holds sway.

The application of mathematical rigor to the study of mollusk skeletogenesis has, however, yielded glimmers of understanding. Raup and Stanley's pioneering work in 1981 illuminated the path forward, a beacon in the darkness of the unknown. Our investigation seeks to illuminate the mechanisms driving evolutionary-developmental change in Prunum, a journey that wends its way through the labyrinthine corridors of ontogeny and phylogeny. By combining mathematical modeling with experimental inquiry, we aim to decipher the secrets of morphological transformation.

X-radiographic images of Prunum species serve as the canvas upon which our investigation is painted. The skeletal parameters distilled from these images are then inscribed upon the tablets of our software program, CerioShell, a tool akin to a cartographer charting the uncharted territories of the mollusk's form. We have crafted hypothetical shell morphologies, a series of possible trajectories that might have been, and thus shed light upon the boundaries of morphological possibility in Prunum. These findings are to be conjoined with experimental and descriptive studies, a union of disparate threads that shall weave a richer tapestry of understanding.

A shell, that most enigmatic of structures, presents itself as a tube traversing the expanse of time and space, its revolutions – the whorls – a spiral around an axis, the columella, an unseen and eternal core. The speed at which these whorls unfold varies, a tempo that governs the cadence of growth. The sutures, those slender lines separating each whorl, stand as sentinels marking the passage of time. The body whorl, the last and largest of these spirals, holds the apex, the highest point of the shell, while the spire, a tapering column, stretches towards the base, the opposite extremity. The aperture, a gateway to the world, serves as the mollusk's entrance and exit, a portal to the realm of the unknown.

A shell can be contemplated from four disparate perspectives: apical, basal, apertural, and abapertural, each a unique window onto the mystery of its form. The apertural view, with the opening oriented towards the observer, is the most common, a vantage point that invites the eye to behold the shell in all its glory.

The whorls, those spiraling coils, can be counted by tracing the first suture, a starting point that marks the initiation of growth. A line drawn from this point divides the shell, and the whorls are enumerated, each one estimated to a quarter turn. This method, a technique akin to charting the constellations on a celestial map, allows us to quantify the passage of time and the unfolding of the shell.

As the mollusk grows, its shell becomes a series of apertures, each one a portal to a new moment in time, a new space traversed by the animal's steady accretion. The trajectory of these apertures can be plotted, a mathematical representation of the shell's growth. This formulation, a language of numbers and symbols, allows us to manipulate the parameters, to vary the tempo and rhythm of the shell's development.

In this manner, we may peer into the very fabric of life, and behold the hidden patterns that govern the unfolding of form and function. The trajectory of the aperture, a thread of continuity, weaves its way through the tapestry of time, a testament to the intricate and beautiful mystery of evolution.

In the marrow of Indonesia's progress, a frigid chill has set in, its icy fingers grasping for the fragile lives of the young. The neonatal and infant mortality rates, once a stubborn bastion of resistance, have remained static for a full decade, defying the ambitions of a nation striving to reclaim its place among the ranks of the living. The targets of the Millennium Development Goals, once within grasp, now recede like a mirage on a desert horizon. The water and sanitation targets, like a parched traveler, have been quenched, but the waters of child and maternal health remain stagnant, their shores a barren wasteland of unfulfilled promise.

The statistics, a cold and unforgiving mistress, reveal a tale of partial victories and lingering despair. Seventy-two percent of births now bear witness to the presence of a skilled health worker, but this dubious triumph masks a deeper truth: the midwives, those tentative guardians of life, are often powerless to stem the tide of complications that wash over their charges. The maternal deaths, a grim testament to this failure, stand as a stark reminder that even the most laudable progress can be a thin veneer, a brittle crust that shatters beneath the weight of reality.

In the rural expanse of Indonesia, the cesarian-section rates hover at an anemic 2%, a stark contrast to the 7% that marks the urban landscape. This chasm, a gulf of inequality, yawns wide, a testament to the entrenched disparities that afflict the nation. The poor, like a shipwrecked castaway, are left to fend for themselves, their access to healthcare services a distant memory, a fleeting dream that vanishes on the winds of poverty.

As the nation grapples with the abyss of neonatal and maternal care, the question hangs in the balance, a choice between two paths: the one that beckons with programmatic solutions, a siren's call that promises swift results and targeted objectives, but also tempts with the dangers of duplication and fragmentation; or the path that seeks to strengthen the health system, a more arduous journey that may yield slower returns, but one that holds the promise of sustainability and equity.

The allure of vertical approaches, like a tantalizing mirage, draws the eye, promising a quick fix, a magic bullet that solves the problem in a single, well-targeted strike. But the costs, like the weight of the desert sands, are crushing: the diversion of resources, the hemorrhaging of human capital, the cacophony of uncoordinated programs that drown out the cries of the suffering. The danger, like a specter, haunts the fringes of this approach, a ghostly presence that whispers of a future where the poor are left to fend for themselves, their health a distant memory, a luxury reserved for the privileged few.

In the labyrinthine world of Victorian fiction, a peculiar subgenre emerged, characterized by an unyielding attention to detail and an affinity for the aristocracy of the era. Two novels that diverged from this tradition, Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights, instead opted for an unorthodox narrative path, replete with mystery and an air of the bizarre. This deliberate departure from the expected served to imbue their characters with a depth and complexity that would otherwise have remained elusive.

The words of Charles Dickens echo through the shadows, a haunting refrain that speaks to the fractured mind of his protagonist: "And now, a host of bewildering and confusing ideas crowded his mind, like specters from a dark and forsaken place. He seemed to still walk among Sikes and Crackit, their angry voices ringing in his ears, their words an endless litany that threatened to consume him whole. And then, like a mirage on a dusty plain, the sound of gunfire shattered the silence, and he felt himself being borne away by some unseen hand, his senses reeling in a maelstrom of pain and confusion."

In these novels, the mysteries unfold like a slow-burning fire, often through the lens of dream sequences or states of altered consciousness. In Oliver Twist, these strange occurrences serve as a window into the depths of Oliver's soul, revealing the dark fears and pains that lurked within. The shooting of Oliver, revisited in chapter 28, becomes a recurring nightmare, a vivid and all-consuming memory that threatens to consume him whole. As he relives the event, the boundaries between reality and fantasy blur, and we are left with the haunting question: who is responsible for his misfortune, and why? The answer, much like the shooting itself, remains shrouded in an impenetrable haze, leaving only the faintest whisper of despair and hopelessness.

The darkness closes in, a suffocating shroud that threatens to extinguish the last vestiges of light. "The day passed off – day! There was no day; it was gone as soon as come – and night came on again; night so long, and yet so short; long in its dreadful silence and short in its fleeting hours." The words of Dickens hang in the air, a mournful dirge that speaks to the futility of human endeavor in the face of an uncaring universe.

In Oliver Twist, this sense of powerlessness is palpable, a crushing weight that threatens to break the spirit. The shooting serves as a stark reminder that Oliver is not the master of his own destiny, that the forces arrayed against him are too strong, too insidious to be defeated. And yet, even in the face of this overwhelming despair, there remains a glimmer of hope, a flickering candle that casts a faint light into the darkness.

It was a dusty afternoon, the kind that seems to cling to the soul like a shroud. I had been working at the after-school program for what felt like an eternity, my days a blur of makeshift lesson plans and weary gazes from the elementary-age students who wandered in each day with their own particular brand of desperation. I had a particular fondness for the written word, and so I found myself drawn to the young boy they called Adrian. He was a small thing, no more than eight years old, with eyes that seemed to hold a depth of sorrow I had seen in few others. They told me he struggled with reading, but I soon discovered that it wasn't quite so simple. Some letters he knew, their shapes and sounds etched into his mind like the lines on a well-worn book. Others, however, left him stumbling, his tongue tangled in knots as he sought to pronounce the alien sounds. It was as if the very language itself had betrayed him, a thief in the night that had stolen his understanding.

We worked together for what felt like an eternity, I and this small, bruised boy. But it wasn't until his mother appeared, a woman with a face like worn leather and eyes that seemed to hold a world of pain, that the truth began to reveal itself to me. She spoke no English, only the soft, melodic language of her people. Our communication was a halting, broken thing, like the staccato beat of a drum on a cold winter's night. And yet, in that moment, something clicked into place. Adrian's struggles, his stumblings, were not the result of some inherent deficiency, but rather a simple matter of unfamiliarity. The English alphabet, once a mystery to him, began to reveal its secrets, and I was left with a newfound appreciation for the complexities of language.

I tell this story, a cautionary tale of the language barrier that separates us, to illustrate the profound obstacles that stand between us and understanding. It is a chasm that yawns wide, a seemingly insurmountable gulf that divides the haves from the have-nots. But I also tell it to suggest that this problem is not always so evident, even to ourselves. We think we know, we think we understand, but the truth is often shrouded in shadows, waiting to be uncovered. In Adrian's case, the solution was simple: one-on-one tutoring, an attentive ear and a gentle hand to guide him through the labyrinth of language. But for the countless others, the answer is far more complicated.

The dual language system, so touted as a panacea for the language-challenged, is but a single thread in the tapestry of solutions. It is a fragile, tenuous thing, a thread that may snap under the weight of expectation. And yet, it holds within it the seeds of hope. For in its gentle, patient approach, we find the key to unlocking the doors of understanding. Children who participate in two-way bilingual education programs have been shown to outperform their peers, to flourish in a world that often seems determined to stifle them. But we must not be fooled into thinking that this is a simple solution, a magic bullet that will somehow solve the problem overnight. It is not.

We must approach this challenge with caution, with empathy, and with a deep understanding of the complexities that lie at its heart. We must recognize that the language barrier is not something that can be bridged with a single solution, but rather a multifaceted problem that requires a multifaceted approach. We must have faith in the power of the human spirit, in the capacity for language to heal and to connect us, even in the darkest of times. And we must be willing to walk the long, winding road that lies before us, with all its twists and turns, its triumphs and setbacks.

This, then, is the question: how do we bridge the chasm that separates us? Do we require all teachers to be bilingual, to be linguists and diplomats and miracle workers, all at once? No, that would be an unreasonable expectation, a bridge too far. But we can, and must, provide them with the tools they need to navigate this complex landscape. We can, and must, provide them with bilingual aids, with tutors, with whatever resources they need to unlock the doors of understanding.

The solution lies not in a single answer, but in a thousand small, incremental steps. It lies in the quiet, patient work of teachers and tutors and caregivers, who toil in the trenches, day after day, to bring forth the hidden talents and abilities of their students. It lies in the recognition that language is not a static thing, a fixed entity that can be learned and mastered, but rather a dynamic, living, breathing creature that must be nurtured and coaxed into being. And it lies, finally, in our willingness to listen, to hear the language of the heart, and to respond with compassion, with understanding, and with a deep and abiding commitment to the beauty and power of the human spirit.

From the earliest dawn of our existence, a whispered promise has been whispered into our ears - a cold wind that stirs the trees of our souls, beckoning us towards the unattainable. Some seek solace in the hallowed halls of Sunday school, while others prowl the musty aisles of Temple, or delve into the dark recesses of their own innermost selves in search of answers. Many cling to the worn and weathered truths of their forebears, while a few reject them outright, scorning the notion that there lies something beyond the narrow confines of our individual domains. We chase the shadows, grasping for a fleeting glimpse of something greater, a light to guide us through the dark and into the desolate vastness of an uncertain future.

My father's eyes, like two worn stones, gazed out into the rain-soaked twilight, the droplets hammering against the tin roof above us like a dirge. We sat on the porch, the gutters overflowing, drowning the parched earth and withered plants that clung to the edge of our domain. The air reeked of smoke and damp earth. His thin frame, gaunt and worn, seemed to sag beneath the weight of his own mortality. His hair, once a wild tangle, now lay sparse and still, a testament to the ravages of time. I felt the weight of his silence, the unspoken words that hung in the air like a challenge. I reached out, wrapped my arms around him, and leaned back into the creaking chair, our bodies a fragile barrier against the encroaching darkness.

He passed five days after my twenty-second birthday, in the cold grasp of December's bitter chill. The poison and radiation had prolonged his suffering, but what price had been paid for these fleeting months, I could not fathom. What kind of deity would orchestrate such a cruel symphony? I lay awake in the dead of night, my breath a whispered curse. If there was a god, I thought, he had long since turned a deaf ear to my pleas.

I had not wished to bear witness to his final passage, to see the light flicker out of his eyes as the life drained from his frame. I could not watch the man who had given me life slip away, his essence dissolving into the void. I chose to remember him as he was, not as he became. And so, I waited, curled into a fetal ball, as the hours ticked by like grains of sand in an hourglass. No one came to claim me, no soft words to ease the ache in my heart.

The Gothic novel, a term freighted with the contradictions of the old and the new, strains against the boundaries of definition. It is a genre born of oxymoron, a marriage of the antiquated and the modern, as Ian Watt so astutely observed in his account of its rise. The Gothic mode has been reviled, extolled, and dissected, its very essence subject to the whims of literary fashion. And yet, despite the capricious nature of critical opinion, the Gothic novel persists, its appeal lying in the dark, terrible beauty it evokes. Edmund Burke's notion of the "sublime" finds its perfect corollary in the Gothic's somber, haunted landscapes, where the shadows of the past converge with the anxieties of the present.

In Horace Walpole's The Castle of Otranto, the ur-text of the Gothic novel, we find the germination of this peculiar alchemy. Walpole, a master of theatricality and mimicry, wove together the disparate threads of ancient romance and modern narrative to create a new and singular form. The "Gothic Story," as he called it, was a deliberate anachronism, a pastiche of medieval theatre, architecture, and tradition. And yet, in its very anachronism lay its power, a power that would endure for centuries, even as the world around it underwent a radical transformation.

The Gothic novel's debt to medieval chivalry is particularly noteworthy. The ideal of the knight, with its attendant values of honor, bravery, and courtesy, was a potent symbol of a bygone era, and one that Walpole and his fellow writers saw as increasingly lost in the present. In The Castle of Otranto, this ideal is embodied in the character of Frederic, a prince of unimpeachable virtue, whose sufferings and travails serve as a commentary on the decay of chivalric values in a world gone awry. The description of Frederic is a tour-de-force of Gothic excess, a hyperbolic portrait of the "gallant and courteous Knight" that sets the tone for the entire genre.

In the midst of a society torn asunder by politics and strife, Walpole's writing becomes a cri de coeur, a lament for the loss of a bygone era of moral certitude. The Gothic novel, with its emphasis on the "terrible sublime," becomes a means of negotiating the abyss between past and present, a bridge of darkness and despair that spans the chasm between two worlds. And it is in this darkness, this abyss, that we find the true power of the Gothic novel, a power that continues to haunt and fascinate us to this day.

In the vast expanse of commerce, a hidden web of processes unravels, a silent dance of goods and materials from the raw, unyielding earth to the eager hands of the consumer. This opaque tapestry is the supply chain, a labyrinthine path that weaves through stages of production, supply, and distribution, each step a deliberate gesture towards the satisfaction of the customer's insatiable hunger.

It was in 1982 that Keith Oliver, a sage advisor, first coined the term supply chain management, a phrase that would come to define the intricate ballet of planning, implementation, and control that governs this secretive realm. The six sacred elements of the supply chain – production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, and information – are the pillars upon which this edifice stands. The managers of commerce, those masters of the obscure, utilize these elements to provide their customers with a service that is at once swift, efficient, and attentive.

Production, the initial step in this grand process, is the very foundation upon which the supply chain is built. It is here that the stage is set, the when, why, where, and how of creation determined. The market, that capricious mistress, holds the key to understanding the desires of the customer, and it is from her whispers that managers glean the knowledge necessary to chart their course. With the market's counsel in hand, they decide what to produce, in what quantities, and where to produce it, ever mindful of the customer's insatiable thirst.

The location of production, that crucial decision, is not taken lightly. Managers must weigh the pros and cons, pitting volume against quality, all the while keeping the customer's satisfaction paramount. And once the location is determined, the focus shifts to scheduling, to the careful allocation of workloads and the maintenance of equipment. Every detail, no matter how seemingly trivial, holds the power to make or break the supply chain, to reap a bounty of time and money, or to sow the seeds of ruin.

I recall my own time in the retail trenches, at the hallowed halls of Wal-Mart and Target, where every step, every gesture, was choreographed with precision, from the design of the employee's uniform to the receipt of shipments. The benefits of such planning are legion: a company that moves with purpose, unencumbered by the weight of confusion and misdirection.

And then, of course, there is supply, that vital element that governs the very fabric of the supply chain. Here, managers must make strategic decisions, weighing the costs and benefits of core capabilities and outsourcing partnerships. A single product may require multiple divisions, each with its own unique equipment, workers, and specializations. The manager must decide which division is best suited to each process, all the while keeping the customer's needs at the forefront. And should the need arise, the manager may choose to outsource, to partner with other companies, in the pursuit of velocity – that elusive quality of providing flexibility and quality at a reduced cost.

The sign creaked in the wind, a splintered message scrawled across its weathered surface: "Hitler is alive in Burma". A solitary figure stood beneath it, a young woman with a face worn by the weight of the world. Ellen Page, a fleeting name from a distant land, held aloft the makeshift placard as if it were a beacon in a desolate landscape. The words, penned in hasty scrawl, seemed to mock her from the page like a cruel jest.

Burma, a land shrouded in shadow, was a nation ruled by an iron fist. A junta of ruthless men, their faces twisted by the lust for power, had seized control in a bloodless coup. The date was etched in history as 1962, a year that marked the beginning of an era of unyielding oppression. The people, their voices silenced by fear, were forced to endure the whims of their oppressors.

In 2007, a flicker of defiance flared to life. Monks, their saffron robes a beacon of hope in a sea of darkness, took to the streets to protest the injustices they had suffered for so long. Their cries for freedom fell on deaf ears, however, as the military junta responded with brutal force. Monasteries were reduced to rubble, foreign journalists were imprisoned and silenced, and the streets ran red with the blood of the innocent.

The death toll, a number that would only grow with time, was a mere whisper of the true horror that had unfolded. Colonel Hla Win, a man who had once been a part of the very machine that had perpetrated these atrocities, now spoke out against it. His words, a testament to the human cost of unchecked power, were a stark reminder of the darkness that lurked within the human heart.

This was not a new tale, nor was it a unique one. The desire to crush dissent, to snuff out the flames of freedom, had been a constant companion to humanity throughout its messy, bloody history. The Roman emperors, gods in their own minds, had ruled with an iron fist. The Japanese emperors, deified by their people, had led them down a path of self-destruction. And in our own time, the leaders of nations had spoken with the voices of gods, their words dripping with venom and deceit.

From the Tiananmen Square massacre to the Rwandan genocide, from the Third Reich to the countless other atrocities that had scarred the face of the earth, the same dark impulse had driven men to commit unspeakable acts. And yet, even as the world mourned the dead and the living trembled with fear, the cycle continued. The desire for power, the lust for control, remained an unquenchable fire that burned at the very heart of humanity.

In the desolate vastness of jazz history, Duke Ellington's legacy stands as a testament to the transience of mortal endeavor. His artistry, a testament to the futility of human endeavor, transcended the confines of time, as his orchestra, a collection of disparate individuals, coalesced into a cohesive entity under his direction. The piano, an instrument often relegated to the periphery, Ellington wielded with a subtlety that belied its importance, his nimble fingers dancing across the keys like a conductor orchestrating the very fabric of reality.

As a composer, Ellington's genius lay in his ability to craft frameworks within which his musicians could unfurl their talents like a lotus blooming in the desert. He wove intricate patterns, a tapestry of sound that showcased the unique timbre of each player, inviting them to improvise, to weave their own narratives within the fabric of his compositions. And thus, the orchestra, an ensemble of disparate voices, coalesced into a single, unified entity, a symphony of sound that echoed through the ages.

The Creole Love Call, a paean to the voice as a jazz instrument, stands as a testament to Ellington's innovative spirit. Like a vessel filled with the scent of decay, this early work, through its use of voice to add texture and color, hinted at the depths of his artistry. The deliberate, plodding pace of this twelve-bar blues, a funeral dirge for the conventions of traditional melody, gave way to six choruses, each a variation on the theme of call and response.

The first chorus, a gentle, melodic whisper, gave way to a raspy, guttural cry, a manifestation of the raw emotion that lay beneath the surface. The muted trumpet solo that followed, a mournful lament, emphasized the bluesy, extended notes that would become a hallmark of Ellington's style. The sweeping clarinet solo, a virtuosic display of agility, was counterpointed by a syncopated piano phrase, a staccato beat that underpinned the entire piece.

The full band, a riotous explosion of sound, echoed the first chorus, a call and response between brass and reeds that echoed the primal, primeval rhythms of the universe. The climactic fifth chorus, a cacophonous maelstrom of sound, saw the reeds take center stage, their call and response a high-pitched, wailing cry that pierced the heavens. And finally, the sixth chorus, a return to the gentle whisper of the first, saw the voice take on the "growl" technique, soloing as an instrument, a primal, animalistic cry that left the listener breathless.

In Hot and Bothered, a work that followed a year later, Ellington combined his mastery of orchestration with his ear for tone color. A call and response phrase between Bubber Miley's muted trumpet and Baby Cox's scat singing created a rich, complementary sound, a marriage of voice and instrument that echoed the primordial, elemental forces that shaped the universe. And in It Don't Mean a Thing (If It Ain't Got That Swing), Joe "Tricky Sam" Nanton, a stalwart of Ellington's orchestra, took center stage, his muted trombone introducing the melody like a benediction from on high.

Thus, Ellington's legacy, a testament to the transience of mortal endeavor, stood as a testament to the power of art to transcend the boundaries of time and space. His music, a paean to the fleeting nature of human experience, echoed through the ages, a reminder of the beauty that lay just beyond the reaches of our mortal grasp.

The void within her lingered, a gnawing ache that refused to subside. It had begun to manifest in her adolescence, a whisper in the darkness, a shadow that trailed her footsteps like a persistent specter. The years had passed, and the hunger remained, a constant presence that seemed to mock her every step. She was 17 now, a threshold of adulthood looming before her, and still the void persisted. It was a hunger that had once been sated by material possessions, but now it had taken on a more insistent form: the desire for connection, for love, for the gentle warmth of another's touch. Yet, she felt an unshakeable detachment from the boys who sought to claim her, their clumsy overtures a farce, a pale imitation of the real thing.

The days blended together in a haze of quietude, her parents a steady, soothing presence in her life. They were a calm sea, untroubled by the turmoil that churned within her. Their tranquility was a balm to her soul, a reminder that she was not entirely lost. But today was not a day of peace. Her mother's cry pierced the air, a sharp, blood-curdling shriek that shook her to her core. She rushed into the kitchen, her heart racing, her mind a jumble of terror and confusion. Her mother lay on the floor, a crumpled, broken thing, her body twisted in an unnatural pose.

"Oh, sweet lord," her mother gasped, her voice a threadbare whisper. "Help me, child." The daughter's hand closed around her mother's, a surge of panic coursing through her veins. "Just get me to the hospital," her mother begged, her voice a desperate rasp. The daughter's mind reeled as she helped her mother to her feet, supporting her weight, her own strength faltering in the face of her mother's pain.

The drive to the hospital was a blur of fear and worry, the scent of disinfectant and sickness hanging heavy in the air. Her mother's face was a mask of agony, her eyes closed in a desperate bid to shut out the pain. The daughter's mind was a jumble of frantic thoughts, her heart pounding in her chest like a drum. What had happened? How had her mother fallen? The questions swirled in her mind like a maelstrom, but she pushed them aside, focusing on the task at hand.

At the hospital, the doctors' faces were a blur of concern and efficiency, their words a distant hum in the background as she helped her mother onto a gurney. They whisked her away, leaving the daughter alone, her mind reeling with fear and worry. Her mother had fallen from a stepping stool, trying to retrieve a vase from a high cabinet. It seemed a trivial thing, a careless mistake, but the daughter knew better. The consequences were all too real, the pain and the fear etched on her mother's face a stark reminder of the fragility of life.

The arid landscape of chronic heart disease and stroke stretched out before us, a desolate expanse of mortality and decay. It was against this bleak backdrop that the Mediterranean Diet, a gaunt and unforgiving mistress, was tested. The alternate Mediterranean diet score, a numerical gauge of adherence to this dietary regime, held the key to unraveling the mysteries of its efficacy. Higher scores, a testament to a diet rich in plant foods, monounsaturated fats, and fish, and bereft of saturated fats and animal products, beckoned the promise of a reduced risk of chronic heart disease and stroke.

Prior studies, like ghostly apparitions, had whispered tales of the Med diet's inverse association with total and cardiovascular mortality. An intervention trial, a fleeting, flickering flame of hope, had shown the Med diet to be a more potent ally in the struggle against weight loss and the ratio of total to high-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the obese. Yet, the specter of stroke, a dark and silent killer, remained unexamined.

In the Nurses' Health Study, a vast and sprawling tapestry of 121,700 female nurses, 74,886 threads were woven into the fabric of this investigation. These women, aged 38 to 63, unencumbered by the weight of cardiovascular disease or diabetes, were the subjects of a 20-year odyssey. Six times, between 1984 and 2004, the authors computed the aMed diet score from self-reported food frequency questionnaires, a litany of nutrient intake that echoed through the years. The FFQs, a testament to the women's diligence, were validated, their truthfulness verified by the cold, unforgiving light of medical records and hospital documents.

The reports of heart disease, fatal and non-fatal, stroke, and death were confirmed, their occurrence leaving an indelible mark on the fabric of this study. In the absence of records, the presence of probable cases, a spectral presence that hung like a shadow, was acknowledged, comprising 17% of all strokes and 24% of non-fatal myocardial infarcts. The tapestry of this study was further enriched by the inclusion of body mass index, smoking status, aspirin use, multivitamin intake, menopausal status, and the use of postmenopausal hormone, each thread intricately woven into the narrative.

To mitigate the capricious nature of individual variation and distill the essence of long-term dietary intake, the authors calculated cumulative averages of the aMed score from the repeated FFQs. The resulting tapestry, a rich and complex weave, was adjusted for the confounders that threatened to obscure the truth: age, smoking, BMI, menopausal status, postmenopausal hormone use, multivitamin intake, alcohol intake, physical activity, and aspirin use.

Cox proportional-hazard modeling, a statistical sorcery, was employed to unravel the association between the aMed score and the risk of CHD and stroke. The results, a stark and unflinching portrait, revealed that adherence to the Mediterranean diet, as reflected by a higher aMed diet score, was indeed associated with a lower risk of incident CHD and stroke in women. The 20-year vigil, a testament to the power of this dietary regime, yielded 2391 incident cases of CHD, 1763 incident cases of stroke, and 1077 cardiovascular disease deaths. Women in the top aMed quintile, a select and privileged few, were found to be at lower risk for both CHD and stroke, their fate sealed by a relative risk of 0.71.

In the ravaged landscape of 2007, a tempest of fiscal despair beset the United States of America, leaving in its wake a trail of shattered dreams and desolate economic ruin. Unemployment reared its head like a specter, the housing market crumbled to dust, and the behemoths of American industry lay shattered, their grandeur reduced to naught but rubble. As we stand amidst this devastation, we are compelled to confront the question that haunts us still: how did this calamity unfold, and how might we avert its recurrence? The truth, like a cadaverous specter, rears its head: a concatenation of selfish and naive political machinations, which coerced banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into a financial infrastructure as fragile as a spider's web.

Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC), those behemoths of the financial world, were goaded into underwriting and repackaging these mortgages into the toxic abominations known as CDOs and CDSs. And when the borrowers defaulted, as was inevitable, the banks were left with the bitter taste of defeat, their capital reserves laid bare and their coffers drained. The chaos thus unleashed was transferred, like a plague, onto the repackaged mortgages they had sold, and thence to the economy at large.

The seeds of this catastrophe were sown in the Clinton era, in the year 1999, when the President, a man driven by ambition and the lust for power, sought to cement his legacy by relaxing lending restrictions. His aim was to boost his popularity, to bask in the adoration of the masses, and to ensure his re-election. But in his zeal, he set in motion a chain of events that would ultimately lead to the sub-prime crisis seven long years later. A prescient Steven Holmes of the New York Times penned a prophetic warning in 1999: "Fannie Mae, the nation's largest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people, and felt pressure from stockholders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits." Holmes foresaw the calamity that would befall the nation, and sounded the alarm: "But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s."

As the years amassed into a gathering storm, the economy teetered on the brink of collapse, threatened by a concatenation of factors. The new and labyrinthine structure of mortgages, replete with adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations (CDOs), ensnared the economy in its deadly coils. The U.S. households, and financial markets in general, became mired in a web of debt, over-leveraged and vulnerable to the slightest perturbation in the housing market.

And so the housing bubble burst, releasing a maelstrom of destruction upon the financial institutions that had bought these mortgage-backed securities. The top five U.S. investment banks reported a staggering $4.1 trillion in mortgage debts in 2007, a figure that accounted for fully 30% of the USA's GDP. The behemoths of Wall Street, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch, were sold for pennies on the dollar, Lehman Brothers was dismantled, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to surrender their independence, becoming commercial banks subject to the strictures of regulation. Fannie and Freddie, those erstwhile titans of the financial world, were left with a mountain of mortgage debt, a staggering $5 trillion, which would eventually necessitate their nationalization in September 2008.

In the depths of a writer's craft, there lies a pitfall so treacherous, it can send readers tumbling into the abyss of boredom or, worse still, driving them to flee in search of more verdant pastures.  This demon is exposition, that insidious force that tempts us to unveil the secrets of our narrative, to spill the beans, so to speak, in a torrent of words that drowns the very essence of our story.  Dr. Merlin's face contorts in a mixture of frustration and dismay as she confronts the page, her eyes scanning the sea of words for a lifeline, a thread to cling to as the exposition threatens to consume her.

For in the heat of creation, it's easy to forget the sage counsel of 'show, don't tell.'  The words "Show, don't tell," echo through the chambers of her mind, a reminder of the perils of succumbing to the siren's call of exposition.  But still, she finds herself lost in a quagmire of information, drowning in the details of a character's past, their history, their loves, their losses.

Exposition, that wily foe, whispers sweet nothings in our ear, tempting us to reveal the backstory, the history, the context.  But it's a double-edged sword, this exposition.  In film, it's the tedious speech of the Ancient Mariner, a core-dump of information that numbs the senses.  In fiction, it's the author's own telling, a voice that, if not checked, can drown out the music of the narrative.

Consider this: a heroine, a beloved, a marriage, a murder.  Two pages of exposition, a paltry two lines of dialogue.  The husband's character, a cipher, a shadow, a mere whisper of his presence in the heroine's life.  But what if we were to breathe life into him?  What if we gave him voice, gave him substance?  We might see in his eyes the depth of his love for her, the way he moves with a quiet confidence, the way he speaks with a gentleness that belies the strength of his character.  We might see in the heroine the way he changed her, the way he enriched her, the way she was drawn to him like a moth to flame.

And when he dies, we would mourn his passing, not just as a plot device, but as a loss, a tragedy, a reminder of the fragility of life.  We would feel the heroine's pain, her grief, her loss.  And in that, we would be drawn closer to her, our connection deepened by the bond we shared with her beloved.

In short, we need to add meat to the bone of the story.  We need to give it flesh, blood, breath.  We need to make the reader care.  For in the end, it's not just about the plot, it's about the people, the characters, the lives we touch, the hearts we break.  And that, that is the true art of storytelling.

I watched the newscast's from Columbus, Ohio, the city's shadows cast long and dark upon the screen. The first, a fleeting glimpse of NBC 4, a broadcast that danced across the air like a moth in flame. It was the thirteenth of August, a day that would leave its mark upon the souls of all who dwelled within these city walls. The lead story, a tale of blood and steel, unfolded like a dark flower blooming in the desert. A man, Shad Hostettler, his face twisted into a visage of malevolence, had brought harm to his wife. The details, scarce as the morning dew, spoke of multiple stab wounds, a life left broken. The anchor's voice, a monotone murmur, barely above a whisper, seemed to imply that this was but a fleeting moment, a brief excursion into the abyss.

The second story, a whispered rumor of violence, spoke of a young life, Travis Buyers, his name etched into the annals of time, his fate hanging in the balance. A shooting, a brutal and senseless act, had left him critically injured, his future far from certain. The SWAT team, a phalanx of steel and determination, moved in, their presence a testament to the darkness that lurked within the city's streets. But the story, it seemed, was already fading, a will-o'-the-wisp that vanished into the ether, leaving behind only the faintest whisper of its existence.

The news continued, a relentless drumbeat of violence and despair. A gunshot hole, a blemish on the Med-Flight helicopter, a reminder that even the skies were not immune to the city's brutal grasp. A .22 caliber bullet, a tiny fragment of metal, had pierced the metal beast, leaving behind a trail of uncertainty. A reward, a paltry five thousand dollars, was offered to those who would dare to speak out against the shadows.

The weather, a mere sideshow, a distraction from the main event, was forecast to bring rain and thunderstorms, a fleeting respite from the heat that clung to the city like a shroud. The temperatures, a mere abstraction, would remain in the mid to low eighties, a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, the natural world persisted.

And then, a story that would leave its mark, a tale of robbery and deceit. A Clime Road UDF, a bastion of commerce, had been breached, its defenses breached by a dark-skinned man, his features obscured by a hoodie, his presence a fleeting glimpse of something primal and unyielding. The anchor's voice, a monotone drone, seemed to linger on the details, to emphasize the darkness of his skin, as if it were a badge of shame.

A final story, a testament to the city's twisted priorities, spoke of Rene Rodriguez, a man convicted of conspiring to distribute marijuana, his fate a mere abstraction, a number, three hundred months, a reminder that even in the depths of the justice system, the numbers game was always played.

A bond forged in blood and fire, unyielding and unbreakable. It is this bond that ties two brothers together, a tangle of emotions that cannot be unraveled - love, pride, jealousy, cruelty, and all the tangled threads that bind them. In the crucible of adversity, this bond is revealed in all its brutal beauty, its true nature laid bare like the scorched earth after a wildfire. And it is here, in this most dire of circumstances, that the true cost of this bond is paid in full.

To gaze into the eyes of one's brother is to behold a reflection of oneself, a mirrored image that reveals the depths of one's own soul. It is in the actions, the words, and the consequences of those actions that the true character of a man is revealed. In "The Scarlet Ibis", two brothers embark on a futile journey, a desperate bid to escape the crushing weight of their own despair. The landscape around them is a lush, verdant tapestry, a mere backdrop for the tragedy that unfolds.

Pride, that most corrosive of emotions, is the thread that weaves throughout this tale. The protagonist's heart is a battleground, a war-scarred terrain where resentment and love clash in a maelstrom of conflicting desires. He had envisioned a brother who would be a mirror image of himself, a companion in arms, a fellow traveler on the path to manhood. But fate, that cruel and capricious mistress, had other plans. Doodle, the younger brother, was a fragile thing, his heart a mere whisper of what it should be. The protagonist's dreams of a brotherly bond, of a shared adventure, were crushed beneath the weight of reality.

And yet, even as his heart festered with resentment, a spark of love remained, a flame that flickered in the darkness. For in Doodle's smile, the protagonist saw a glimmer of hope, a reminder that even in the darkest depths of despair, there is always a glimmer of redemption. This is a man torn asunder by his own contradictions, a soul wrestling with the demons of his own making.

In the end, it is not the outcome of their journey that matters, but the journey itself, the twisted, tortured path that leads to the climactic moment of truth. And it is here, in this moment, that the true nature of the bond between brothers is revealed, a bond that is at once beautiful and terrible, cruel and redemptive.

In the darkest recesses of the human mind, a labyrinthine complexity unfolds, a tapestry of thought woven from the threads of perception. As the ages pass, the parlance of description has evolved, a litany of metaphors born from the crude and the refined. We once likened the cerebral cortex to a wax tablet, a crude slate upon which the marks of knowledge were etched. Then to a sheet of papyrus, its pockmarked surface bearing the weight of hieroglyphic knowledge. And further still, to a book, its pages dog-eared and worn from the fingers of countless readers. And now, in the virtual expanse of the modern era, to a computer, its algorithms a cold, calculating heartbeat.

But these metaphors, like the fleeting shadows on a wall, are mere approximations, their utility bound by the constraints of language. For in the depths of the brain, a primal alchemy unfolds, as sensory impressions are transmuted into electrochemical impulses. The senses, those doorkeepers of the mind, receive the raw material of the world: the gentle caress of a summer breeze, the scorching heat of a desert sun, the sonorous thrum of a guitar string, or the piercing light of a desert star. These impressions are then transformed, refined, and reassembled by the brain's own peculiar logic, a dialectic of bottom-up and top-down processing.

In the former, the building blocks of perception are painstakingly assembled, a mosaic of color, shape, and texture. A black box on a white background, for instance, is recognized through the gradual accumulation of these elementary data points. And yet, it is the top-down processing that imbues this recognition with meaning, that gives the box its significance, its context. For it is through this process that we identify the box not merely as a shape, but as a container, a vessel, a thing.

But perception is a fleeting thing, a will-o'-the-wisp that vanishes at the merest whisper of distraction. And so, the brain must prioritize, filter out the irrelevant, and focus on the essential. The attention filter, that sentinel of the mind, stands guard, determining which signals are worthy of consideration, which are but fleeting shadows, to be discarded like so many autumn leaves on a winter's wind.

And yet, even as the brain filters and prioritizes, it must also store, encode, and maintain the information it receives. There are multiple types of memory, each with its own peculiar logic, its own rhythms and cadences. Sensory memory, that fleeting whisper of the present, gives way to working memory, that brief, shining moment of recall, and long-term memory, that vast, labyrinthine repository of knowledge.

The encoding of information is a process of translation, a mapping of the raw data of the world onto the brain's own peculiar syntax. Verbal input, for instance, can be encoded through its structure, its sound, or its meaning. And once encoded, this information must be maintained, sustained by the electrical impulses that fire through the neural networks, like the steady beat of a drum.

But how is this knowledge organized, this vast, unwieldy tapestry of thought? The semantic network, a model of the mind's inner workings, posits a web of interconnected nodes, each representing a concept, a meaning, a thing. "Chair," for instance, is linked to "table," which is linked to "wooden," and so forth. And so, the mind's vast, labyrinthine library is revealed, a boundless expanse of thought, where meaning and connection await the curious, the inquiring mind.

In the sterile expanse of Brave New World, Aldous Huxley lays bare the dystopian trajectory of a world enthralled by the siren song of technology and the crushing weight of capitalist excess. A people conditioned to crave the fleeting pleasures of immediate gratification, they forsake the depths of individuality for the shallow comforts of a collective existence. The World Controller pulls the strings, orchestrating a grand farce in which the masses are reduced to pawns, their thoughts and desires shaped to conform to the dictates of a singular ideology.

Through the lens of Marxist theo-philosophy, we discern the author's implicit suspicions regarding the perils of emerging systems that spawn and sustain this bleak world. The terminology of Marxism – homogeny, reification, and the like – serves as a litany, a testament to Huxley's prescience regarding the insidious effects of unchecked capitalism. The false consciousness, a concept dear to Marxist thought, is here wielded as a satirical tool, laying bare the ways in which the common citizenry is denied knowledge of their true relations with other classes, their gaze fixed instead on the fleeting pleasures of consumption and indulgence.

The Delta and Gamma classes, those bound to the drudgery of menial labor, are denied the gift of self-awareness, their desires honed to a razor's edge by the relentless drumbeat of hypnopædia. The World Controller manipulates this docility, orchestrating a grand farce in which the underclasses are bought into an ideology that serves to entrench their subjugation. Hegemony, that insidious force that reduces disparate groups to a state of subjugation, is wielded with ruthless efficiency, the ruling classes aping the behavior of their overlords, their awareness of the game's true nature limited to a rarefied few, like Bernard, whose rebellion is as much a product of his own privilege as it is a genuine assertion of individuality.

In this bleak landscape, relationships between individuals are reduced to the most superficial of levels, the characters themselves little more than cardboard cutouts, devoid of depth or nuance. Love, that most fundamental of human emotions, is an anathema, replaced by the sterile, transactional interactions that pass for human connection in this dystopian world. The males and females, their interactions reduced to shallow, mercantile transactions, their words dripping with the calculating cynicism of a world in which love has been reduced to a commodity. The complacency of each social class, their acceptance of their lot in life, serves as a stark testament to the insidious effects of capitalism, a system that reduces individuals to mere ciphers, their agency stripped away by the relentless drumbeat of consumption and obedience.

The years have worn down the miles, four and a half semesters of traversing the sprawling expanse of University Park. A student for nigh on three years now, I've come to know the trials of navigating this campus like the lines on a weathered face. The East Halls, once a distant sentinel on the edge of town, now stand as a testament to the voracious appetite of progress. The vacant lots that once separated the dormitories from the rest of the university have given way to a tapestry of sports fields, sleek new buildings, and apartment complexes. The Creamery, a hub of activity, stands as a beacon, its presence a reminder of the ceaseless expansion that threatens to consume us all.

The land itself seems to stretch on forever, a vast and unforgiving expanse that demands to be traversed. And so I find myself on the move, a restless spirit driven by the need to reach my destinations. The solution, I've come to realize, lies not in the bike itself, but in the resolve of those who would wield it. For in the stillness of the morning, before the day's din awakens, I've found solace in the rhythm of pedaling. The wind in my hair, the sun on my face, and the world unfolding before me – it is a sensation that frees the soul.

A friend, one who'd abandoned the saddle for years, recently took up the practice once more. His words still echo in my mind: "Bikes are great, for a few years it wasn't cool to ride a bike, but it's the only way to get around." And so I've taken to the road, a daily commute to Thomas building, a journey that would take an eternity to complete on foot. The minutes tick by like grains of sand, each one a reminder of the preciousness of time. But the bike, ah, the bike – it distills the journey to a mere five minutes, a fleeting instant that leaves me breathless and wanting more.

Yet, even this small victory is not without its costs. Pollock Road, a straight shot to my destination, is a road beset on all sides by the hazards of the world. The bike, a fragile vessel, must navigate the treacherous waters of existence, ever vigilant for the hidden perils that lurk in every shadow. And so I ride, a solitary figure, a fleeting glimpse of movement in a world that's increasingly indifferent to our plight.

In the end, it's not just a matter of getting from point A to point B – it's a question of existence itself. The bike is a symbol of freedom, a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there is beauty to be found in the simple act of movement. And so I'll continue to ride, a small voice in the wilderness, a testament to the power of the human spirit to persevere in the face of adversity.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
In order for the brain to process information, it must first be stored. There are multiple types of memory, including sensory, working, and long-term. First, information is encoded. There are types of encoding specific to each type of sensory stimuli. For example, verbal input can be encoded structurally, referring to what the printed word looks like, phonemically, referring to what the word sounds like, or semantically, referring to what the word means. Once information is stored, it must be maintained. Some animal studies suggest that working memory, which stores information for roughly 20 seconds, is maintained by an electrical signal looping through a particular series of neurons for a short period of time. Information in long-term memory is hypothesized to be maintained in the structure of certain types of proteins.
There are numerous models of how the knowledge is organized in the brain, some based on the way human subjects retrieve memories, others based on computer science, and others based on neurophysiology. The semantic network model states that there are nodes representing concepts, and that the nodes are linked based on their relatedness. For example, in a semantic network, “chair” might be linked to “table,” which can be linked to “wooden,” and so forth.

In 2007, the United States of America fell into a crushing financial crisis. Unemployment increased, the housing market crashed, and many of America’s largest and most important corportations were left in ruin. This recession persists today, so we must ask the question: how did this crisis occur, and how can we stop it? In short, the financial crisis was created by selfish and naïve political decision-making that pressured banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into an already immature and unsufficient financial infrastructure. Meanwhile, Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC) were pressured to underwite and repackage these mortgages into CDO’s and CDS’. When borrowers defaulted on these loans, the banks were short on capital reserve and transferred this chaos onto the repacked mortgages that they had sold, and on to the rest of the economy.
	The financial crisis had its roots in 1999 of the Clinton era, as the President was aiming for a second term in office. He sought to extend his presidential tenure by augmenting his popularity. To accomplish this the Clinton administration relaxed lending restrictions, which helped to set the grim stage for the sub-prime crisis seven years later.  Steven Holmes of the New York Times reported in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” Holmes would go on to correctly foresee the consequences of these actions: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As detailed in the introduction, and as Holmes foresaw, ill-advised lending would certainly lead to the meltdown of the economy.
	Many factors combined to throw the economy into tailspin, one of which was the new and complex structure of mortgages. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations (CDO’s) were all used extensively in the years leading up to the crisis, and only served to intertwine more sectors of the economy into the housing market. This led to U.S. households, and financial markets in general, to overleverage themselves in the housing market, leaving them extremely vulnerable to even small changes in price. 
	Indeed, the housing bubble burst, and the financial institutions that had bought these mortgage-backed securities were spited. The top five U.S. investment banks all together reported $4.1 trillion dollars of mortgage debts in 2007, which accounted for about 30% of the USA’s GDP. In the end, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch were sold exceptionally cheap, Lehman Brothers was dismantled, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to become commercial banks subjected to intense regulation. Fannie and Freddie were $5 trillion in mortgage debt, and were placed under government control in September 2008.

Ah, exposition.  That place in your story where you stretch your little writer's wings and take flight, astounding one and all with your magnetic, nay magical prose.  Or the part where your readers fall asleep and/or hit the "Back" button while cursing your name.  Dr. Merlin has been known to shout at her monitor when she finds herself in the middle of Too Much Information, and not even in the fun way.

Exposition is not your friend.

My gentle readers already know the basic writing tip, "Show, don't tell," but Dr. Merlin still stumbles into long passages of text where nothing happens, or worse, too much.  Exposition is the little devil sitting on your shoulder that says to get the history out of the way to get to the good parts (not to be confused with the devil sitting on the other shoulder urging the author to tell her audience every single detail of the childhoods of each character).
